chapters.text: Jake stood frozen in the doorway of the robotics club, clutching his backpack straps so tightly his knuckles turned white. Twenty pairs of eyes stared back at him. The room buzzed with the sounds of small motors and excited chatter that instantly died when he appeared. A tall girl with bright blue hair stepped forward. "You lost?" she asked, raising an eyebrow. Jake swallowed hard. After three schools in two years, he knew the drill - lay low, don't stand out, make a few safe friends. But something about this school felt different. Maybe it was time to try something new. "Actually, I signed up for robotics," he said, his voice cracking slightly. The girl grinned and extended her hand. "Cool! I'm Mia. Fair warning though - once you're in our club, there's no going back. We're like family here. Nobody betrays family."

Jake took Mia's hand, surprised by her firm handshake. "I'm Jake," he replied, trying to sound confident. Mia led him through the room, introducing him to the other club members who were working on various robot parts. In the corner, a small robot was attempting to pick up a carton of milk and pour it into a cup - failing spectacularly as milk splashed everywhere. "That's our current challenge," Mia explained, laughing. "We're building helper robots for the school cafeteria, but the milk-pouring function is giving us trouble." She handed Jake a towel to help clean up. "What do you think? Any ideas?" Jake studied the robot's gripper mechanism, noticing a design flaw. For the first time in years, he felt a spark of excitement. Maybe this was his chance to belong somewhere, to use the engineering skills he'd been teaching himself between school transfers.

Jake took a deep breath and pushed open the door to the robotics lab. Inside, five students huddled around a metal contraption with wires sticking out in all directions. A girl with curly hair looked up and smiled. "You must be Jake! I'm Mia. Welcome to our little family." She waved him over to the table where a robot arm repeatedly tried and failed to pick up a milk carton. "We're stuck on the cafeteria helper project. This thing keeps crushing the cartons." Jake set his backpack down and studied the gripper. The problem was obvious - the pressure sensors weren't calibrated properly. "What if we add a flexible material between the metal fingers?" he suggested, sketching a quick design on his notebook. The team looked impressed. "That might work!" Mia exclaimed, placing a paper crown on Jake's head. "All hail the new robotics king!" Everyone laughed, and for the first time in years, Jake felt like he belonged.

As the laughter died down, Jake looked around the robotics lab with new eyes. The walls covered in blueprints and shelves stacked with spare parts felt welcoming now. He spotted an old safety helmet on a workbench, its visor cracked but still usable. "Hey, what if we add a helmet-mounted display for the cafeteria robots?" Jake suggested, pointing to the discarded headgear. "The lunch ladies could see what the robots see." Mia's eyes widened as she grabbed the helmet. "That's brilliant! We've been struggling with the navigation system for weeks." Mr. Peterson, the club advisor, nodded approvingly. "This could solve our blind spot problem." Jake smiled as the team gathered around, sketching modifications on scrap paper. Between all his school transfers, he'd taught himself enough engineering to recognize good design, but never had people to share ideas with. Now his knowledge had found a home.

Jake smiled as he placed his circuit diagram on the table, watching the other club members gather around. For years, he had studied robotics from library books and online videos during his family's constant moves. Mia leaned over his shoulder, her eyes widening at his solution for the gripper problem. "This could actually work," she said, pointing to his redesigned claw mechanism. The cafeteria helper robot needed to handle trays without dropping them, and Jake's design added flexible silicone pads shaped like cat paws for better grip. Mr. Chen, the club advisor, nodded approvingly. "The PAW design distributes pressure more evenly," Jake explained, his voice growing stronger with each word. The other students began asking questions and suggesting improvements, no longer seeing him as just the new kid. For the first time in six schools, Jake felt like he belonged somewhere.

Jake stood at the doorway of the robotics lab, clutching his backpack tightly. The room buzzed with activity as students huddled around tables covered with metal parts, wires, and tools. A tall girl with curly hair noticed him and walked over. "You must be Jake! I'm Mia," she said with a friendly smile. "Welcome to our little family." She led him to a table where a half-built robot sat. The team explained they were building helper robots for the school cafeteria. As Jake examined the prototype, he immediately spotted a problem with the gripper mechanism. "This joint won't hold the lunch trays," he said quietly. The room fell silent. Jake's heart raced - had he overstepped? Then Mia's face broke into a grin. "That's exactly what we've been struggling with! How did you know?" Jake relaxed a little. His self-taught engineering skills from all those lonely nights between school transfers were finally useful.

Jake cleared his throat and pointed to the robot's gripper. "If you adjust the tension here and recalibrate the sensors, it'll handle the lunch trays without dropping them," he explained. The robotics club members exchanged impressed glances. Mia smiled encouragingly. "That's exactly what we've been struggling with for weeks!" Over the next month, Jake worked alongside his new friends, programming and building. Their cafeteria helper robot won first place at the district competition. Principal Chen even announced the robot would be used in their actual cafeteria. At the celebration, Mia handed Jake a small bottle labeled "Official Robotics Club Magic Potion" - actually just blue sports drink. "For our newest family member," she said, raising her own bottle. Jake grinned, finally feeling at home. No more lonely nights tinkering by himself. Here, his skills weren't just useful - they were valued, and so was he.
